books.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 1

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 1:1
verses.text: The Refutation of All Heresies Book : System of the Astrologers; Sidereal Influence; Configuration of the Stars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 1:2
verses.text: But in each zodiacal sign they call limits of the stars those in which each of the stars, from any one quarter to another, can exert the greatest amount of influence; in regard of which there is among them, according to their writings, no mere casual divergency of opinion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 1:3
verses.text: But they say that the stars are attended as if by satellites when they are in the midst of other stars, in continuity with the signs of the Zodiac; as if, when any particular star may have occupied the first portions of the same sign of the Zodiac, and another the last, and another those portions in the middle, that which is in the middle is said to be guarded by those holding the portions at the extremities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 1:4
verses.text: And they are said to look upon one another, and to be in conjunction with one another, as if appearing in a triangular or quadrangular figure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 1:5
verses.text: They assume, therefore, the figure of a triangle, and look upon one another, which have an intervening distance extending for three zodiacal signs; and they assume the figure of a square those which have an interval extending for two signs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 1:6
verses.text: But as the underlying parts sympathize with the head, and the head with the underlying parts, so also things terrestrial with superlunar objects.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 1:7
verses.text: But there is of these a certain difference and want of sympathy, so that they do not involve one and the same point of juncture.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 2

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 2:1
verses.text: Doctrines Concerning aeons; The Chaldean Astrology; Heresy Derivable from It.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 2:2
verses.text: Employing these (as analogies), Euphrates the Peratic, and Acembes the Carystian, and the rest of the crowd of these (speculators), imposing names different from the doctrine of the truth, speak of a sedition of aeons, and of a revolt of good powers over to evil (ones), and of the concord of good with wicked (aeons), calling them Toparchai and Proastioi, and very many other names.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 2:3
verses.text: But the entire of this heresy, as attempted by them, I shall explain and refute when we come to treat of the subject of these (aeons).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 2:4
verses.text: But now, lest any one suppose the opinions propounded by the Chaldeans respecting astrological doctrine to be trustworthy and secure, we shall not hesitate to furnish a brief refutation respecting these, establishing that the futile art is calculated both to deceive and blind the soul indulging in vain expectations, rather than to profit it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 2:5
verses.text: And we urge our case with these, not according to any experience of the art, but from knowledge based on practical principles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 2:6
verses.text: Those who have cultivated the art, becoming disciples of the Chaldeans, and communicating mysteries as if strange and astonishing to men, having changed the names (merely), have from this source concocted their heresy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 2:7
verses.text: But since, estimating the astrological art as a powerful one, and availing themselves of the testimonies adduced by its patrons, they wish to gain reliance for their own attempted conclusions, we shall at present, as it has seemed expedient, prove the astrological art to be untenable, as our intention next is to invalidate also the Peratic system, as a branch growing out of an unstable root.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:1
verses.text: The Horoscope the Foundation of Astrology; Indiscoverability of the Horoscope; Therefore the Futility of the Chaldean Art.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:2
verses.text: The originating principle, and, as it were, foundation, of the entire art, is fixing the horoscope.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:3
verses.text: For from this are derived the rest of the cardinal points, as well as the declinations and ascensions, the triangles and squares, and the configurations of the stars in accordance with these; and from all these the predictions are taken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:4
verses.text: Whence, if the horoscope be removed, it necessarily follows that neither any celestial object is recognisable in the meridian, or at the horizon, or in the point of the heavens opposite the meridian; but if these be not comprehended, the entire system of the Chaldeans vanishes along with (them).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:5
verses.text: But that the sign of the horoscope is indiscoverable by them, we may show by a variety of arguments.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:6
verses.text: For in order that this (horoscope) may be found, it is first requisite that the (time of) birth of the person falling under inspection should be firmly fixed; and secondly, that the horoscope which is to signify this should be infallible; and thirdly, that the ascension of the zodiacal sign should be observed with accuracy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:7
verses.text: For from (the moment) of birth the ascension of the zodiacal sign rising in the heaven should be closely watched, since the Chaldeans, determining (from this) the horoscope, frame the configuration of the stars in accordance with the ascension (of the sign); and they term this—disposition, in accordance with which they devise their predictions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:8
verses.text: But neither is it possible to take the birth of persons, falling under consideration, as I shall explain, nor is the horoscope infallible, nor is the rising zodiacal sign apprehended with accuracy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:9
verses.text: How it is, then, that the system of the Chaldeans is unstable, let us now declare.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:10
verses.text: Having, then, previously marked it out for investigation, they draw the birth of persons falling under consideration from, unquestionably, the depositing of the seed, and (from) conception or from parturition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:11
verses.text: And if one will attempt to take (the horoscope) from conception, the accurate account of this is incomprehensible, the time (occupied) passing quickly, and naturally (so).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:12
verses.text: For we are not able to say whether conception takes place upon the transference of the seed or not.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:13
verses.text: For this can happen even as quick as thought, just also as leaven, when put into heated jars, immediately is reduced to a glutinous state.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:14
verses.text: But conception can also (take place) after a lapse of duration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:15
verses.text: For there being an interval from the mouth of the womb to the fundament, where physicians say conceptions take place, it is altogether the nature of the seed deposited to occupy some time in traversing this interval.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:16
verses.text: The Chaldeans, therefore, being ignorant of the quantity of duration to a nicety, never will comprehend the (moment of) conception; the seed at one time being injected straight forward, and falling at one spot upon actual parts of the womb well disposed for conception, and at another time dropping into it dispersedly, and being collected into one place by uterine energies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:17
verses.text: Now, while these matters are unknown, (namely), as to when the first takes place, and when the second, and how much time is spent in that particular conception, and how much in this; while, I say, ignorance on these points prevails on the part of these (astrologers), an accurate comprehension of conception is put out of the question.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:18
verses.text: And if, as some natural philosophers have asserted, the seed, remaining stationary first, and undergoing alteration in the womb, then enters the (womb's) opened blood-vessels, as the seeds of the earth sink into the ground; from this it will follow, that those who are not acquainted with the quantity of time occupied by the change, will not be aware of the precise moment of conception either.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:19
verses.text: And, moreover, as women differ from one another in the other parts of the body, both as regards energy and in other respects, so also (it is reasonable to suppose that they differ from one another) in respect of energy of womb, some conceiving quicker, and others slower.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:20
verses.text: And this is not strange, since also women, when themselves compared with themselves, at times are observed having a strong disposition towards conception, but at times with no such tendency.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 3:21
verses.text: And when this is so, it is impossible to say with accuracy when the deposited seed coalesces, in order that from this time the Chaldeans may fix the horoscope of the birth.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:1
verses.text: Impossibility of Fixing the Horoscope; Failure of an Attempt to Do This at the Period of Birth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:2
verses.text: For this reason it is impossible to fix the horoscope from the (period of) conception.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:3
verses.text: But neither can this be done from (that of) birth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:4
verses.text: For, in the first place, there exists the difficulty as to when it can be declared that there is a birth; whether it is when the foetus begins to incline towards the orifice, or when it may project a little, or when it may be borne to the ground.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:5
verses.text: Neither is it in each of these cases possible to comprehend the precise moment of parturition, or to define the time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:6
verses.text: For also on account of disposition of soul, and on account of suitableness of body, and on account of choice of the parts, and on account of experience in the midwife, and other endless causes, the time is not the same at which the foetus inclines towards the orifice, when the membranes are ruptured, or when it projects a little, or is deposited on the ground; but the period is different in the case of different individuals.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:7
verses.text: And when the Chaldeans are not able definitely and accurately to calculate this, they will fail, as they ought, to determine the period of emergence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:8
verses.text: That, then, the Chaldeans profess to be acquainted with the horoscope at the periods of birth, but in reality do not know it, is evident from these considerations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:9
verses.text: But that neither is their horoscope infallible, it is easy to conclude.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:10
verses.text: For when they allege that the person sitting beside the woman in travail at the time of parturition gives, by striking a metallic rim, a sign to the Chaldean, who from an elevated place is contemplating the stars, and he, looking towards heaven, marks down the rising zodiacal sign; in the first place, we shall prove to them, that when parturition happens indefinitely, as we have shown a little before, neither is it easy to signify this (birth) by striking the metallic rim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:11
verses.text: However, grant that the birth is comprehensible, yet neither is it possible to signify this at the exact time; for as the noise of the metallic plate is capable of being divided by a longer time and one protracted, in reference to perception, it happens that the sound is carried to the height (with proportionate delay).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:12
verses.text: And the following proof may be observed in the case of those felling timber at a distance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:13
verses.text: For a sufficiently long time after the descent of the axe, the sound of the stroke is heard, so that it takes a longer time to reach the listener.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:14
verses.text: And for this reason, therefore, it is not possible for the Chaldeans accurately to take the time of the rising zodiacal sign, and consequently the time when one can make the horoscope with truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 4:15
verses.text: And not only does more time seem to elapse after parturition, when he who is sitting beside the woman in labour strikes the metallic plate, and next after the sound reaches the listener, that is, the person who has gone up to the elevated position; but also, while he is glancing around and looking to ascertain in which of the zodiacal signs is the moon, and in which appears each of the rest of the stars, it necessarily follows that there is a different position in regard of the stars, the motion of the pole whirling them on with incalculable velocity, before what is seen in the heavens is carefully adjusted to the moment when the person is born.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:1
verses.text: Another Method of Fixing the Horoscope at Birth; Equally Futile; Use of the Clepsydra in Astrology; The Predictions of the Chaldeans Not Verified.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:2
verses.text: In this way, the art practised by the Chaldeans will be shown to be unstable.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:3
verses.text: Should any one, however, allege that, by questions put to him who inquires from the Chaldeans, the birth can be ascertained, not even by this plan is it possible to arrive at the precise period.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:4
verses.text: For if, supposing any such attention on their part in reference to their art to be on record, even these do not attain—as we have proved—unto accuracy either, how, we ask, can an unsophisticated individual comprehend precisely the time of parturition, in order that the Chaldean acquiring the requisite information from this person may set the horoscope correctly? But neither from the appearance of the horizon will the rising star seem the same everywhere; but in one place its declination will be supposed to be the horoscope, and in another the ascension (will be thought) the horoscope, according as the places come into view, being either lower or higher.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:5
verses.text: Wherefore, also, from this quarter an accurate prediction will not appear, since many may be born throughout the entire world at the same hour, each from a different direction observing the stars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:6
verses.text: But the supposed comprehension (of the period of parturition) by means of clepsydras is likewise futile.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:7
verses.text: For the contents of the jar will not flow out in the same time when it is full as when it is half empty; yet, according to their own account, the pole itself by a single impulse is whirled along at an equable velocity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:8
verses.text: If, however, evading the argument, they should affirm that they do not take the time precisely, but as it happens in any particular latitude, they will be refuted almost by the sidereal influences themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:9
verses.text: For those who have been born at the same time do not spend the same life, but some, for example, have been made kings, and others have grown old in fetters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:10
verses.text: There has been born none equal, at all events, to Alexander the Macedonian, though many were brought forth along with him throughout the earth; (and) none equal to the philosopher Plato.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:11
verses.text: Wherefore the Chaldean, examining the time of the birth in any particular latitude, will not be able to say accurately, whether a person born at this time will be prosperous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:12
verses.text: Many, I take it, born at this time, have been unfortunate, so that the similarity according to dispositions is futile.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:13
verses.text: Having, then, by different reasons and various methods, refuted the ineffectual mode of examination adopted by the Chaldeans, neither shall we omit this, namely, to show that their predictions will eventuate in inexplicable difficulties.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:14
verses.text: For if, as the mathematicians assert, it is necessary that one born under the barb of Sagittarius' arrow should meet with a violent death, how was it that so many myriads of the Barbarians that fought with the Greeks at Marathon or Salamis were simultaneously slaughtered? For unquestionably there was not the same horoscope in the case, at all events, of them all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:15
verses.text: And again, it is said that one born under the urn of Aquarius will suffer shipwreck: (yet) how is it that so many of the Greeks that returned from Troy were overwhelmed in the deep around the indented shores of Euboea? For it is incredible that all, distant from one another by a long interval of duration, should have been born under the urn of Aquarius.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:16
verses.text: For it is not reasonable to say, that frequently, for one whose fate it was to be destroyed in the sea, all who were with him in the same vessel should perish.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 5:17
verses.text: For why should the doom of this man subdue the (destinies) of all? Nay, but why, on account of one for whom it was allotted to die on land, should not all be preserved?.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 6

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 6:1
verses.text: Zodiacal Influence; Origin of Sidereal Names.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 6:2
verses.text: But since also they frame an account concerning the action of the zodiacal signs, to which they say the creatures that are procreated are assimilated, neither shall we omit this: as, for instance, that one born in Leo will be brave; and that one born in Virgo will have long straight hair, be of a fair complexion, childless, modest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 6:3
verses.text: These statements, however, and others similar to them, are rather deserving of laughter than serious consideration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 6:4
verses.text: For, according to them, it is possible for no aethiopian to be born in Virgo; otherwise he would allow that such a one is white, with long straight hair and the rest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 6:5
verses.text: But I am rather of opinion, that the ancients imposed the names of received animals upon certain specified stars, for the purpose of knowing them better, not from any similarity of nature; for what have the seven stars, distant one from another, in common with a bear, or the five stars with the head of a dragon?—in regard of which Aratus says:—  "But two his temples, and two his eyes, and one beneath  Reaches the end of the huge monster's jaw".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7:1
verses.text: Practical Absurdity of the Chaldaic Art; Development of the Art.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7:2
verses.text: In this manner also, that these points are not deserving so much labour, is evident to those who prefer to think correctly, and do not attend to the bombast of the Chaldeans, who consign monarchs to utter obscurity, by perfecting cowardice in them, and rouse private individuals to dare great exploits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7:3
verses.text: But if any one, surrendering himself to evil, is guilty of delinquency, he who has been thus deceived does not become a teacher to all whom the Chaldeans are disposed to mislead by their mistakes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7:4
verses.text: (Far from it); (these astrologers) impel the minds (of their dupes, as they would have them), into endless perturbation, (when) they affirm that a configuration of the same stars could not return to a similar position, otherwise than by the renewal of the Great Year, through a space of seven thousand seven hundred and seventy and seven years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7:5
verses.text: How then, I ask, will human observation for one birth be able to harmonize with so many ages; and this not once, (but oftentimes, when a destruction of the world, as some have stated, would intercept the progress of this Great Year; or a terrestrial convulsion, though partial, would utterly break the continuity of the historical tradition)? The Chaldaic art must necessarily be refuted by a greater number of arguments, although we have been reminding (our readers) of it on account of other circumstances, not peculiarly on account of the art itself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7:6
verses.text: Since, however, we have determined to omit none of the opinions advanced by Gentile philosophers, on account of the notorious knavery of the heretics, let us see what they also say who have attempted to propound doctrines concerning magnitudes,—who, observing the fruitless labour of the majority (of speculators), where each after a different fashion coined his own falsehoods and attained celebrity, have ventured to make some greater assertion, in order that they might be highly magnified by those who mightily extol their contemptible lies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7:7
verses.text: These suppose the existence of circles, and measures, and triangles, and squares, both in twofold and threefold array.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 7:8
verses.text: Their argumentation, however, in regard of this matter, is extensive, yet it is not necessary in reference to the subject which we have taken in hand.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:1
verses.text: Prodigies of the Astrologers; System of the Astronomers; Chaldean Doctrine of Circles; Distances of the Heavenly Bodies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:2
verses.text: I reckon it then sufficient to declare the prodigies detailed by these men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:3
verses.text: Wherefore, employing condensed accounts of what they affirm, I shall turn my attention to the other points (that remain to be considered).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:4
verses.text: Now they make the following statements.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:5
verses.text: The Creator communicated pre-eminent power to the orbital motion of the identical and similar (circle), for He permitted the revolution of it to be one and indivisible; but after dividing this internally into six parts, (and thus having formed) seven unequal circles, according to each interval of a twofold and threefold dimension, He commanded, since there were three of each, that the circles should travel in orbits contrary to one another, three indeed (out of the aggregate of seven) being whirled along with equal velocity, and four of them with a speed dissimilar to each other and to the remaining three, yet (all) according to a definite principle.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:6
verses.text: For he affirms that the mastery was communicated to the orbital motion of the same (circle), not only since it embraces the motion of the other, that, is, the erratic stars, but because also it possesses so great mastery, that is, so great power, that even it leads round, along with itself, by a peculiar strength of its own, those heavenly bodies—that is, the erratic stars—that are whirled along in contrary directions from west to east, and, in like manner, from east to west.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:7
verses.text: And he asserts that this motion was allowed to be one and indivisible, in the first place, inasmuch as the revolutions of all the fixed stars were accomplished in equal periods of time, and were not distinguished according to greater or less portions of duration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:8
verses.text: In the next place, they all present the same phase as that which belongs to the outermost motion; whereas the erratic stars have been distributed into greater and varying periods for the accomplishment of their movements, and into unequal distances from earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:9
verses.text: And he asserts that the motion in six parts of the other has been distributed probably into seven circles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:10
verses.text: For as many as are sections of each (circle)—I allude to monads of the sections—become segments; for example, if the division be by one section, there will be two segments; if by two, three segments; and so, if anything be cut into six parts, there will be seven segments.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 8:11
verses.text: And he says that the distances of these are alternately arranged both in double and triple order, there being three of each,—a principle which, he has attempted to prove, holds good of the composition of the soul likewise, as depending upon the seven numbers.

verses.text: For among them there are from the monad three double (numbers), viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 9:1
verses.text: Further Astronomic Calculations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 9:2
verses.text: The mutual distances of the circles and spheres, and the depths, are rendered by Archimedes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 9:3

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:1
verses.text: Theory of Stellar Motion and Distance in Accordance with Harmony.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:2
verses.text: Concerning the Moon, however, a statement has been previously made.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:3
verses.text: The distances and profundities of the spheres Archimedes thus renders; but a different declaration regarding them has been made by Hipparchus; and a different one still by Apollonius the mathematician.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:4
verses.text: It is sufficient, however, for us, following the Platonic opinion, to suppose twofold and threefold distances from one another of the erratic stars; for the doctrine is thus preserved of the composition of the universe out of harmony, on concordant principles in keeping with these distances.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:5
verses.text: The numbers, however, advanced by Archimedes, and the accounts rendered by the rest concerning the distances, if they be not on principles of symphony,—that is, the double and triple (distances) spoken of by Plato,—but are discovered independent of harmonies, would not preserve the doctrine of the formation of the universe according to harmony.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:6
verses.text: For it is neither credible nor possible that the distances of these should be both contrary to some reasonable plan, and independent of harmonious and proportional principles, except perhaps only the Moon, on account of wanings and the shadow of the Earth, in regard also of the distance of which alone—that is, the lunar (planet) from earth—one may trust Archimedes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:7
verses.text: It will, however, be easy for those who, according to the Platonic dogma itself, adopt this distance to comprehend by numerical calculation (intervals) according to what is double and triple, as Plato requires, and the rest of the distances.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:8
verses.text: If, then, according to Archimedes, the Moon is distant from the surface of the Earth ,, stadii, by increasing these numbers double and triple, (it will be) easy to find also the distances of the rest, as if subtracting one part of the number of stadii which the Moon is distant from the Earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:9
verses.text: But because the rest of the numbers—those alleged by Archimedes concerning the distance of the erratic stars—are not based on principles of concord, it is easy to understand—that is, for those who attend to the matter—how the numbers are mutually related, and on what principles they depend.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:10
verses.text: That, however, they should not be in harmony and symphony—I mean those that are parts of the world which consists according to harmony—this is impossible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:11
verses.text: Since, therefore, the first number which the Moon is distant from the earth is ,,, the second number which the Sun is distant from the Moon being ,,, subsists by a greater computation than ninefold.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:12
verses.text: But the higher number in reference to this, being ,,, is (comprised) in a greater computation than half.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:13
verses.text: The number, however, superior to this, which is ,,, is contained in a greater computation than half.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:14
verses.text: But the number superior to this, which is ,,, is contained in a less computation than two-fifths.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:15
verses.text: But the number superior to this, which is ,,, is contained in a greater computation than half.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 10:16
verses.text: The final number, however, which is ,,, is comprised in a less computation than double.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11:1
verses.text: Theory of the Size of the Heavenly Bodies in Accordance with Numerical Harmonies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11:2
verses.text: These (numerical) relations, therefore, the greater than ninefold, and less than half, and greater than double, and less than two-fifths, and greater than half, and less than double, are beyond all symphonies, from which not any proportionate or harmonic system could be produced.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11:3
verses.text: But the whole world, and the parts of it, are in all respects similarly framed in conformity with proportion and harmony.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11:4
verses.text: The proportionate and harmonic relations, however, are preserved—as we have previously stated—by double and triple intervals.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11:5
verses.text: If, therefore, we consider Archimedes reliable in the case of only the first distance, that from the Moon to the Earth, it is easy also to find the rest (of the intervals), by multiplying (them) by double and treble.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11:6
verses.text: Let then the distance, according to Archimedes, from Earth to Moon be ,, stadii; there will therefore be the double number of this of stadii which the Sun is distant from the Moon, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11:7
Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 11:8
verses.text: But the Sun is distant from the Earth ,, stadii; and Venus is likewise distant from the Sun ,, stadii, but from the Earth ,, stadii; and Mercury is distant from Venus ,, stadii, but from Earth ,, stadii; and Mars is distant from Mercury ,, stadii, and from Earth ,, stadii; and Jupiter is distant from Mars ,, stadii, but from Earth ,, stadii; Saturn is distant from Jupiter ,, stadii, but from Earth ,, stadii.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 12

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 12:1
verses.text: Waste of Mental Energy in the Systems of the Astrologers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 12:2
verses.text: Who will not feel astonishment at the exertion of so much deep thought with so much toil? This Ptolemy, however—a careful investigator of these matters—does not seem to me to be useless; but only this grieves (one), that being recently born, he could not be of service to the sons of the giants, who, being ignorant of these measures, and supposing that the heights of heaven were near, endeavoured in vain to construct a tower.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 12:3
verses.text: And so, if at that time he were present to explain to them these measures, they would not have made the daring attempt ineffectually.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 12:4
verses.text: But if any one profess not to have confidence in this (astronomer's calculations), let him by measuring be persuaded (of their accuracy); for in reference to those incredulous on the point, one cannot have a more manifest proof than this.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 12:5
verses.text: O, pride of vain-toiling soul, and incredible belief, that Ptolemy should be considered pre-eminently wise among those who have cultivated similar wisdom!.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 13

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 13:1
verses.text: Mention of the Heretic Colarbasus; Alliance Between Heresy and the Pythagorean Philosophy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 13:2
verses.text: Certain, adhering partly to these, as if having propounded great conclusions, and supposed things worthy of reason, have framed enormous and endless heresies; and one of these is Colarbasus, who attempts to explain religion by measures and numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 13:3
verses.text: And others there are (who act) in like manner, whose tenets we shall explain when we commence to speak of what concerns those who give heed to Pythagorean calculation as possible; and uttering vain prophecies, hastily assume as secure the philosophy by numbers and elements.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 13:4
verses.text: Now certain (speculators), appropriating similar reasonings from these, deceive unsophisticated individuals, alleging themselves endued with foresight; sometimes, after uttering many predictions, happening on a single fulfilment, and not abashed by many failures, but making their boast in this one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 13:5
verses.text: Neither shall I pass over the witless philosophy of these men; but, after explaining it, I shall prove that those who attempt to form a system of religion out of these (aforesaid elements), are disciples of a school weak and full of knavery.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:1
verses.text: System of the Arithmeticians; Predictions Through Calculations; Numerical Roots; Transference of These Doctrines to Letters; Examples in Particular Names; Different Methods of Calculation; Prescience Possible by These.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:2
verses.text: Those, then, who suppose that they prophesy by means of calculations and numbers, and elements and names, constitute the origin of their attempted system to be as follows.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:3
verses.text: They affirm that there is a root of each of the numbers; in the case of thousands, so many monads as there are thousands: for example, the root of six thousand, six monads; of seven thousand, seven monads; of eight thousand, eight monads; and in the case of the rest, in like manner, according to the same (proportion).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:4
verses.text: And in the case of hundreds, as many hundreds as there are, so many monads are the root of them: for instance, of seven hundred there are seven hundreds; the root of these is seven monads: of six hundred, six hundreds; the root of these, six monads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:5
verses.text: And it is similar respecting decades: for of eighty (the root is) eight monads; and of sixty, six monads; of forty, four monads; of ten, one monad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:6
verses.text: And in the case of monads, the monads themselves are a root: for instance, of nine, nine; of eight, eight; of seven, seven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:7
verses.text: In this way, also, ought we therefore to act in the case of the elements (of words), for each letter has been arranged according to a certain number: for instance, the letter n according to fifty monads; but of fifty monads five is the root, and the root of the letter n is (therefore) five.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:8
verses.text: Grant that from some name we take certain roots of it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:9
verses.text: For instance, (from) the name Agamemnon, there is of the a, one monad; and of the g, three monads; and of the other a, one monad; of the m, four monads; of the e, five monads; of the m, four monads; of the n, five monads; of the (long) o, eight monads; of the n, five monads; which, brought together into one series, will be , , , , , , , , ; and these added together make up  monads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:10
verses.text: Again, they take the roots of these, and they become three in the case of the number thirty, but actually six in the case of the number six.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:11
verses.text: The three and the six, then, added together, constitute nine; but the root of nine is nine: therefore the name Agamemnon terminates in the root nine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:12
verses.text: Let us do the same with another name—Hector.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:13
verses.text: The name (H)ector has five letters—e, and k, and t, and o, and r.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:14
verses.text: The roots of these are , , , , ; and these added together make up  monads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:15
verses.text: Again, of the ten the root is one; and of the nine, nine; which added together make up ten: the root of ten is a monad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:16
verses.text: The name Hector, therefore, when made the subject of computation, has formed a root, namely a monad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:17
verses.text: It would, however, be easier to conduct the calculation thus: Divide the ascertained roots from the letters—as now in the case of the name Hector we have found nineteen monads—into nine, and treat what remains over as roots.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:18
verses.text: For example, if I divide  into , the remainder is , for  times  are , and there is a remaining monad: for if I subtract  from , there is a remaining monad; so that the root of the name Hector will be a monad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:19
verses.text: Again, of the name Patroclus these numbers are roots: , , , , , , , , ; added together, they make up  monads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:20
verses.text: And of these the remainder is  monads: of the , ; and of the ,.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:21
verses.text: Seven monads, therefore, are the root of the name Patroclus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:22
verses.text: Those, then, that conduct their calculations according to the rule of the number nine, take the ninth part of the aggregate number of roots, and define what is left over as the sum of the roots.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:23
verses.text: They, on the other hand, (who conduct their calculations) according to the rule of the number seven, take the seventh (part of the aggregate number of roots); for example, in the case of the name Patroclus, the aggregate in the matter of roots is  monads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:24
verses.text: This divided into seven parts makes four, which (multiplied into each other) are.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:25
verses.text: There are six remaining monads; (so that a person using this method) says, according to the rule of the number seven, that six monads are the root of the name Patroclus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:26
verses.text: If, however, it be , (six) taken seven times, he says, are , for seven times six are , and one is the remainder.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:27
verses.text: A monad, therefore, is the root of the number , according to the rule of the number seven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:28
verses.text: But one ought to observe if the assumed number, when divided, has no remainder; for example, if from any name, after having added together the roots, I find, to give an instance,  monads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:29
verses.text: But the number  divided into nine makes exactly  enneads; for nine times  are , and nothing is over.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:30
verses.text: It is evident, then, that the actual root is.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:31
verses.text: And again, dividing the number forty-five, we find nine and nothing over—for nine times five are forty-five, and nothing remains; (wherefore) in the case of such they assert the root itself to be nine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:32
verses.text: And as regards the number seven, the case is similar: if, for example we divide  into , we have nothing over; for seven times four are , and nothing remains; (wherefore) they say that seven is the root.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:33
verses.text: But when one computes names, and finds the same letter occurring twice, he calculates it once; for instance, the name Patroclus has the pa twice, and the o twice: they therefore calculate the a once and the o once.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:34
verses.text: According to this, then, the roots will be , , , , , , , , and added together they make  monads; and the root of the name will be, according to the rule of the number nine, nine itself, but according to the rule of the number seven, six.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:35
verses.text: In like manner, (the name) Sarpedon, when made the subject of calculation, produces as a root, according to the rule of the number nine, two monads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:36
verses.text: Patroclus, however, produces nine monads; Patroclus gains the victory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:37
verses.text: For when one number is uneven, but the other even, the uneven number, if it is larger, prevails.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:38
verses.text: But again, when there is an even number, eight, and five an uneven number, the eight prevails, for it is larger.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:39
verses.text: If, however, there were two numbers, for example, both of them even, or both of them odd, the smaller prevails.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:40
verses.text: But how does (the name) Sarpedon, according to the rule of the number nine, make two monads, since the letter (long) o is omitted? For when there may be in a name the letter (long) o and (long) e, they leave out the (long) o, using one letter, because they say both are equipollent; and the same must not be computed twice over, as has been above declared.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:41
verses.text: Again, (the name) Ajax makes four monads; (but the name) Hector, according to the rule of the ninth number, makes one monad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:42
verses.text: And the tetrad is even, whereas the monad odd.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:43
verses.text: And in the case of such, we say, the greater prevails—Ajax gains the victory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:44
verses.text: Again, Alexander and Menelaus (may be adduced as examples).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:45
verses.text: Alexander has a proper name (Paris).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:46
verses.text: But Paris, according to the rule of the number nine, makes four monads; and Menelaus, according to the rule of the number nine, makes nine monads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:47
verses.text: The nine, however, conquer the four (monads): for it has been declared, when the one number is odd and the other even, the greater prevails; but when both are even or both odd, the less (prevails).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:48
verses.text: Again, Amycus and Polydeuces (may be adduced as examples).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:49
verses.text: Amycus, according to the rule of the number nine, makes two monads, and Polydeuces, however, seven: Polydeuces gains the victory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:50
verses.text: Ajax and Ulysses contended at the funeral games.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:51
verses.text: Ajax, according to the rule of the number nine, makes four monads; Ulysses, according to the rule of the number nine, (makes) eight.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:52
verses.text: Is there, then, not any annexed, and (is there) not a proper name for Ulysses? for he has gained the victory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:53
verses.text: According to the numbers, no doubt, Ajax is victorious, but history hands down the name of Ulysses as the conqueror.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:54
verses.text: Achilles and Hector (may be adduced as examples).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:55
verses.text: Achilles, according to the rule of the number nine, makes four monads; Hector one: Achilles gains the victory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:56
verses.text: Again, Achilles and Asteropaeus (are instances).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:57
verses.text: Achilles makes four monads, Asteropaeus three: Achilles conquers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:58
verses.text: Again, Menelaus and Euphorbus (may be adduced as examples).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:59
verses.text: Menelaus has nine monads, Euphorbus eight: Menelaus gains the victory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:60
verses.text: Some, however, according to the rule of the number seven, employ the vowels only, but others distinguish by themselves the vowels, and by themselves the semi-vowels, and by themselves the mutes; and, having formed three orders, they take the roots by themselves of the vowels, and by themselves of the semi-vowels, and by themselves of the mutes, and they compare each apart.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:61
verses.text: Others, however, do not employ even these customary numbers, but different ones: for instance, as an example, they do not wish to allow that the letter p has as a root  monads, but , and that the (letter) x (si) has as a root four monads; and turning in every direction, they discover nothing sound.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 14:62
verses.text: When, however, they contend about the second (letter), from each name they take away the first letter; but when they contend about the third (letter), they take away two letters of each name, and calculating the rest, compare them.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15:1
verses.text: Quibbles of the Numerical Theorists; The Art of the Frontispicists (Physiognomy); Connection of This Art with Astrology; Type of Those Born Under Aries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15:2
verses.text: I think that there has been clearly expounded the mind of arithmeticians, who, by means of numbers and of names, suppose that they interpret life.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15:3
verses.text: Now I perceive that these, enjoying leisure, and being trained in calculation, have been desirous that, through the art delivered to them from childhood, they, acquiring celebrity, should be styled prophets.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15:4
verses.text: And they, measuring the letters up (and) down, have wandered into trifling.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15:5
verses.text: For if they fail, they say, in putting forward the difficulty, Perhaps this name was not a family one, but imposed, as also lighting in the instance they argue in the case of (the names) Ulysses and Ajax.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15:6
verses.text: Who, taking occasion from this astonishing philosophy, and desirous of being styled "Heresiarch," will not be extolled?  But since, also, there is another more profound art among the all-wise speculators of the Greeks—to whom heretical individuals boast that they attach themselves as disciples, on account of their employing the opinions of these (ancient philosophers) in reference to the doctrines attempted (to be established) by themselves, as shall a little afterwards be proved; but this is an art of divination, by examination of the forehead or rather, I should say, it is madness: yet we shall not be silent as regards this (system).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15:7
verses.text: There are some who ascribe to the stars figures that mould the ideas and dispositions of men, assigning the reason of this to births (that have taken place) under particular stars; they thus express themselves: Those who are born under Aries will be of the following kind: long head, red hair, contracted eyebrows, pointed forehead, eyes grey and lively, drawn cheeks, long-nosed, expanded nostrils, thin lips, tapering chin, wide mouth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 15:8
verses.text: These, he says, will partake of the following nature: cautious, subtle, perspicuous, prudent, indulgent, gentle, over-anxious, persons of secret resolves fitted for every undertaking, prevailing more by prudence than strength, deriders for the time being, scholars, trustworthy, contentious, quarrellers in a fray, concupiscent, inflamed with unnatural lust, reflective, estranged from their own homes, giving dissatisfaction in everything, accusers, like madmen in their cups, scorners, year by year losing something serviceable in friendship through goodness; they, in the majority of cases, end their days in a foreign land.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 16

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 16:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Taurus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 16:2
verses.text: Those, however, who are born in Taurus will be of the following description: round head, thick hair, broad forehead, square eyes, and large black eyebrows; in a white man, thin veins, sanguine, long eyelids, coarse huge ears, round mouths, thick nose, round nostrils, thick lips, strong in the upper parts, formed straight from the legs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 16:3
verses.text: The same are by nature pleasing, reflective, of a goodly disposition, devout, just, uncouth, complaisant, labourers from twelve years, quarrelsome, dull.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 16:4
verses.text: The stomach of these is small, they are quickly filled, forming many designs, prudent, niggardly towards themselves, liberal towards others, beneficent, of a slow body: they are partly sorrowful, heedless as regards friendship, useful on account of mind, unfortunate.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 17

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 17:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Gemini.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 17:2
verses.text: Those who are born in Gemini will be of the following description: red countenance, size not very large, evenly proportioned limbs, black eyes as if anointed with oil, cheeks turned down, and large mouth, contracted eyebrows; they conquer all things, they retain whatever possessions they acquire, they are extremely rich, penurious, niggardly of what is peculiarly their own, profuse in the pleasures of women, equitable, musical, liars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 17:3
verses.text: And the same by nature are learned, reflective, inquisitive, arriving at their own decisions, concupiscent, sparing of what belongs to themselves, liberal, quiet, prudent, crafty, they form many designs, calculators, accusers, importunate, not prosperous, they are beloved by the fair sex, merchants; as regards friendship, not to any considerable extent useful.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 18

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 18:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Cancer.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 18:2
verses.text: Those born in Cancer are of the following description: size not large, hair like a dog, of a reddish colour, small mouth, round head, pointed forehead, grey eyes, sufficiently beautiful, limbs somewhat varying.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 18:3
verses.text: The same by nature are wicked, crafty, proficients in plans, insatiable, stingy, ungracious, illiberal, useless, forgetful; they neither restore what is another's, nor do they ask back what is their own; as regards friendship, useful.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 19

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 19:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Leo.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 19:2
verses.text: Those born in Leo are of the following description: round head, reddish hair, huge wrinkled forehead, coarse ears, large development of neck, partly bald, red complexion, grey eyes, large jaws, coarse mouth, gross in the upper parts, huge breast, the under limbs tapering.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 19:3
verses.text: The same are by nature persons who allow nothing to interfere with their own decision, pleasing themselves, irascible, passionate, scorners, obstinate, forming no design, not loquacious, indolent, making an improper use of leisure, familiar, wholly abandoned to pleasures of women, adulterers, immodest, in faith untrue, importunate, daring, penurious, spoliators, remarkable; as regards fellowship, useful; as regards friendship, useless.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 20

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 20:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Virgo.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 20:2
verses.text: Those born in Virgo are of the following description: fair appearance, eyes not large, fascinating, dark, compact eyebrows, cheerful, swimmers; they are, however, slight in frame, beautiful in aspect, with hair prettily adjusted, large forehead, prominent nose.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 20:3
verses.text: The same by nature are docile, moderate, intelligent, sportive, rational, slow to speak, forming many plans; in regard of a favour, importunate; gladly observing everything; and well-disposed pupils, they master whatever they learn; moderate, scorners, victims of unnatural lusts, companionable, of a noble soul, despisers, careless in practical matters, attending to instruction, more honourable in what concerns others than what relates to themselves; as regards friendship, useful.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 21

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 21:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Libra.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 21:2
verses.text: Those born in Libra will be of the following description: hair thin, drooping, reddish and longish, forehead pointed (and) wrinkled, fair compact eyebrows, beautiful eyes, dark pupils, long thin ears, head inclined, wide mouth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 21:3
verses.text: The same by nature are intelligent, God-fearing, communicative to one another, traders, toilers, not retaining gain, liars, not of an amiable disposition, in business or principle true, free-spoken, beneficent, illiterate, deceivers, friendly, careless, (to whom it is not profitable to do any act of injustice); they are scorners, scoffers, satirical, illustrious, listeners, and nothing succeeds with these; as regards friendship, useful.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 22

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 22:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Scorpio.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 22:2
verses.text: Those born in Scorpio are of the following description: a maidenish countenance, comely, pungent, blackish hair, well-shaped eyes, forehead not broad, and sharp nostril, small contracted ears, wrinkled foreheads, narrow eyebrows, drawn cheeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 22:3
verses.text: The same by nature are crafty, sedulous, liars, communicating their particular designs to no one, of a deceitful spirit, wicked, scorners, victims to adultery, well-grown, docile; as regards friendship, useless.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 23

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 23:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Sagittarius.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 23:2
verses.text: Those born in Sagittarius will be of the following description: great length, square forehead, profuse eyebrows, indicative of strength, well-arranged projection of hair, reddish (in complexion).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 23:3
verses.text: The same by nature are gracious, as educated persons, simple, beneficent; given to unnatural lusts, companionable, toil-worn, lovers, beloved, jovial in their cups, clean, passionate, careless, wicked; as regards friendship, useless; scorners, with noble souls, insolent, crafty; for fellowship, useful.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 24

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 24:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Capricorn.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 24:2
verses.text: Those born in Capricorn will be of the following description: reddish body, projection of greyish hair, round mouth, eyes as of an eagle, contracted brows, open forehead, somewhat bald, in the upper parts of the body endued with more strength.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 24:3
verses.text: The same by nature are philosophic, scorners, and scoffers at the existing state of things, passionate, persons that can make concessions, honourable, beneficent, lovers of the practice of music, passionate in their cups, mirthful, familiar, talkative, given to unnatural lusts, genial, amiable, quarrelsome lovers, for fellowship well disposed.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 25

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 25:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Aquarius.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 25:2
verses.text: Those born in Aquarius will be of the following description: square in size, of a diminutive body; sharp, small, fierce eyes; imperious, ungenial, severe, readily making acquisitions, for friendship and fellowship well disposed; moreover, for maritime enterprises they make voyages, and perish.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 25:3
verses.text: The same by nature are taciturn, modest, sociable, adulterers, penurious, practised in business, tumultuous, pure, well-disposed, honourable, large eyebrows; frequently they are born in the midst of trifling events, but (in after life) follow a different pursuit; though they may have shown kindness to any one, still no one returns them thanks.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 26

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 26:1
verses.text: Type of Those Born Under Pisces.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 26:2
verses.text: Those born in Pisces will be of the following description: of moderate dimensions, pointed forehead like fishes, shaggy hair, frequently they become soon grey.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 26:3
verses.text: The same by nature are of exalted soul, simple, passionate, penurious, talkative; in the first period of life they will be drowsy; they are desirous of managing business by themselves, of high repute, venturesome, emulous, accusers, changing their locality, lovers, dancers; for friendship, useful.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 27

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 27:1
verses.text: Futility of This Theory of Stellar Influence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 27:2
verses.text: Since, therefore, we have explained the astonishing wisdom of these men, and have not concealed their overwrought art of divination by means of contemplation, neither shall I be silent as regards (undertakings) in the case of which those that are deceived act foolishly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 27:3
verses.text: For, comparing the forms and dispositions of men with names of stars, how impotent their system is! For we know that those originally conversant with such investigations have called the stars by names given in reference to propriety of signification and facility for future recognition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 27:4
verses.text: For what similarity is there of these (heavenly bodies) with the likeness of animals, or what community of nature as regards conduct and energy (is there in the two cases), that one should allege that a person born in Leo should be irascible, and one born in Virgo moderate, or one born in Cancer wicked, but that those born in….

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:1
verses.text: System of the Magicians; Incantations of Demons; Secret Magical Rites.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:2
verses.text: … And (the sorcerer), taking (a paper), directs the inquirer to write down with water whatever questions he may desire to have asked from the demons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:3
verses.text: Then, folding up the paper, and delivering it to the attendant, he sends him away to commit it to the flames, that the ascending smoke may waft the letters to demons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:4
verses.text: While, however, the attendant is executing this order, (the sorcerer) first removes equal portions of the paper, and on some more parts of it he pretends that demons write in Hebrew characters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:5
verses.text: Then burning an incense of the Egyptian magicians, termed Cyphi, he takes these (portions of paper) away, and places them near the incense.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:6
verses.text: But (that paper) which the inquirer happens to have written (upon), having placed on the coals, he has burned.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:7
verses.text: Then (the sorcerer), appearing to be borne away under divine influence, (and) hurrying into a corner (of the house), utters a loud and harsh cry, and unintelligible to all,…and orders all those present to enter, crying out (at the same time), and invoking Phryn, or some other demon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:8
verses.text: But after passing into the house, and when those that were present stood side by side, the sorcerer, flinging the attendant upon a bed, utters to him several words, partly in the Greek, and partly, as it were, the Hebrew language, (embodying) the customary incantations employed by the magicians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:9
verses.text: (The attendant), however, goes away to make the inquiry.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:10
verses.text: And within (the house), into a vessel full of water (the sorcerer) infusing copperas mixture, and melting the drug, having with it sprinkled the paper that forsooth had (the characters upon it) obliterated, he forces the latent and concealed letters to come once more into light; and by these he ascertains what the inquirer has written down.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:11
verses.text: And if one write with copperas mixture likewise, and having ground a gall nut, use its vapour as a fumigator, the concealed letters would become plain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:12
verses.text: And if one write with milk, (and) then scorch the paper, and scraping it, sprinkle and rub (what is thus scraped off) upon the letters traced with the milk, these will become plain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:13
verses.text: And urine likewise, and sauce of brine, and juice of euphorbia, and of a fig, produce a similar result.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:14
verses.text: But when (the sorcerer) has ascertained the question in this mode, he makes provision for the manner in which he ought to give the reply.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:15
verses.text: And next he orders those that are present to enter, holding laurel branches and shaking them, and uttering cries, and invoking the demon Phryn.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:16
verses.text: For also it becomes these to invoke him; and it is worthy that they make this request from demons, which they do not wish of themselves to put forward, having lost their minds.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:17
verses.text: The confused noise, however, and the tumult, prevent them directing attention to those things which it is supposed (the sorcerer) does in secret.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:18
verses.text: But what these are, the present is a fair opportunity for us to declare.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:19
verses.text: Considerable darkness, then, prevails.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:20
verses.text: For the (sorcerer) affirms that it is impossible for mortal nature to behold divine things, for that to hold converse (with these mysteries) is sufficient.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:21
verses.text: Making, however, the attendant lie down (upon the couch), head foremost, and placing by each side two of those little tablets, upon which had been inscribed in, forsooth, Hebrew characters, as it were names of demons, he says that (a demon) will deposit the rest in their ears.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:22
verses.text: But this (statement) is requisite, in order that some instrument may be placed beside the ears of the attendant, by which it is possible that he signify everything which he chooses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:23
verses.text: First, however, he produces a sound that the (attendant) youth may be terrified; and secondly, he makes a humming noise; then, thirdly, he speaks through the instrument what he wishes the youth to say, and remains in expectation of the issue of the affair; next, he makes those present remain still, and directs the (attendant) to signify, what he has heard from the demons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:24
verses.text: But the instrument that is placed beside his ears is a natural instrument, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:25
verses.text: , the windpipe of long-necked cranes, or storks, or swans.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:26
verses.text: And if none of these is at hand, there are also some different artificial instruments (employed); for certain pipes of brass, ten in number, (and) fitting into one another, terminating in a narrow point, are adapted (for the purpose), and through these is spoken into the ear whatsoever the (magician) wishes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:27
verses.text: And the youth hearing these (words) with terror as uttered by demons, when ordered, speaks them out.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:28
verses.text: If any one, however, putting around a stick a moist hide, and having dried it and drawn it together, close it up, and by removing the rod fashion the hide into the form of a pipe, he attains a similar end.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:29
verses.text: Should any of these, however, be not at hand, he takes a book, and, opening it inside, stretches it out as far as he think requisite, (and thus) achieves the same result.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:30
verses.text: But if he knows beforehand that one is present who is about to ask a question, he is the more ready for all (contingencies).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:31
verses.text: If, however, he may also previously ascertain the question, he writes (it) with the drug, and, as being prepared, he is considered more skilful, on account of having clearly written out what is (about) being asked.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:32
verses.text: If, however, he is ignorant of the question, he forms conjectures, and puts forth something capable of a doubtful and varied interpretation, in order that the oracular response, being originally unintelligible, may serve for numerous purposes, and in the issue of events the prediction may be considered correspondent with what actually occurs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:33
verses.text: Next, having filled a vessel with water, he puts down (into it) the paper, as if uninscribed, at the same time infusing along with it copperas mixture.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:34
verses.text: For in this way the paper written upon floats upwards (to the surface), bearing the response.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:35
verses.text: Accordingly there ensue frequently to the attendant formidable fancies, for also he strikes blows plentifully on the terrified (bystanders).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:36
verses.text: For, casting incense into the fire, he again operates after the following method.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:37
verses.text: Covering a lump of what are called "fossil salts" with Etruscan wax, and dividing the piece itself of incense into two parts, he throws in a grain of salt; and again joining (the piece) together, and placing it on the burning coals, he leaves it there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:38
verses.text: And when this is consumed, the salts, bounding upwards, create the impression of, as it were, a strange vision taking place.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:39
verses.text: And the dark-blue dye which has been deposited in the incense produces a blood-red flame, as we have already declared.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:40
verses.text: But (the sorcerer) makes a scarlet liquid, by mixing wax with alkanet, and, as I said, depositing the wax in the incense.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 28:41
verses.text: And he makes the coals be moved, placing underneath powdered alum; and when this is dissolved and swells up like bubbles, the coals are moved.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 29

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 29:1
verses.text: Display of Different Eggs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 29:2
verses.text: But different eggs they display after this manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 29:3
verses.text: Perforating the top at both ends, and extracting the white, (and) having again dipped it, throw in some minium and some writing ink.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 29:4
verses.text: Close, however, the openings with refined scrapings of the eggs, smearing them with fig-juice.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 30

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 30:1
verses.text: Self-Slaughter of Sheep.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 30:2
verses.text: By those who cause sheep to cut off their own heads, the following plan is adopted.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 30:3
verses.text: Secretly smearing the throat (of the animal) with a cauterizing drug, he places a sword near, and leaves it there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 30:4
verses.text: The sheep, desirous of scratching himself, rushes against the blade, and in the act of rubbing is slaughtered, while the head is almost severed from the trunk.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 30:5
verses.text: There is, however, a compound of the drug, bryony and salt and squills, made up in equal parts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 30:6
verses.text: In order that the person bringing the drug may escape notice, he carries a box with two compartments constructed of horn, the visible one of which contains frankincense, but the secret one (the aforesaid) drug.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 30:7
verses.text: He, however, likewise insinuates into the ears of the sheep about to meet death quicksilver; but this is a poisonous drug.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:1
verses.text: Method of Poisoning Goats.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:2
verses.text: And if one smear the ears of goats over with cerate, they say that they expire a little afterwards, by having their breathing obstructed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:3
verses.text: For this to them is the way—as these affirm—of their drawing their breath in an act of respiration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:4
verses.text: And a ram, they assert, dies, if one bends back (its neck) opposite the sun.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:5
verses.text: And they accomplish the burning of a house, by daubing it over with the juice of a certain fish called dactylus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:6
verses.text: And this effect, which it has by reason of the sea-water, is very useful.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:7
verses.text: Likewise foam of the ocean is boiled in an earthen jar along with some sweet ingredients; and if you apply a lighted candle to this while in a seething state, it catches the fire and is consumed; and (yet though the mixture) be poured upon the head, it does not burn it at all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:8
verses.text: If, however, you also smear it over with heated resin, it is consumed far more effectually.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 31:9
verses.text: But he accomplishes his object better still, if also he takes some sulphur.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:1
verses.text: Imitations of Thunder, and Other Illusions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:2
verses.text: Thunder is produced in many ways; for stones very numerous and unusually large, being rolled downwards along wooden planks, fall upon plates of brass, and cause a sound similar to thunder.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:3
