verses.text: And also around the thin plank with which carders thicken cloth, they coil a thin rope; and then drawing away the cord with a whirr, they spin the plank round, and in its revolution it emits a sound like thunder.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:4
verses.text: These farces, verily, are played off thus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:5
verses.text: There are, however, other practices which I shall explain, which those who execute these ludicrous performances estimate as great exploits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:6
verses.text: Placing a cauldron full of pitch upon burning coals, when it boils up, (though) laying their hands down upon it, they are not burned; nay, even while walking on coals of fire with naked feet, they are not scorched.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:7
verses.text: But also setting a pyramid of stone on a hearth, (the sorcerer) makes it get on fire, and from the mouth it disgorges a volume of smoke, and that of a fiery description.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:8
verses.text: Then also putting a linen cloth upon a pot of water, throwing on (at the same time) a quantity of blazing coals, (the magician) keeps the linen cloth unconsumed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:9
verses.text: Creating also darkness in the house, (the sorcerer) alleges that he can introduce gods or demons; and if any requires him to show aesculapius, he uses an invocation couched in the following words:—  "The child once slain, again of Phoebus deathless made,  I call to come, and aid my sacrificial rites;  Who, also, once the countless tribes of fleeting dead,  In ever-mournful homes of Tartarus wide,  The fatal billow breasting, and the inky flood  Surmounting, where all of mortal mould must float,  Torn, beside the lake, with endless grief and woe,  Thyself didst snatch from gloomy Proserpine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 32:10
verses.text: Or whether the seat of Holy Thrace thou haunt, or lovely  Pergamos, or besides Ionian Epidaurus,  The chief of seers, O happy God, invites thee here".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:1
verses.text: The Burning aesculapius; Tricks with Fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:2
verses.text: But after he discontinues uttering these jests, a fiery aesculapius appears upon the floor.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:3
verses.text: Then, placing in the midst a pot full of water, he invokes all the deities, and they are present.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:4
verses.text: For any one who is by, glancing into the pot, will behold them all, and Diana leading on her baying hounds.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:5
verses.text: We shall not, however, shrink from narrating the account (of the devices) of these men, how they attempt (to accomplish their jugglery).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:6
verses.text: For (the magician) lays his hand upon the cauldron of pitch, which is in, as it were, a boiling state; and throwing in (at the same time) vinegar and nitre and moist pitch, he kindles a fire beneath the cauldron.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:7
verses.text: The vinegar, however, being mixed along with the nitre, on receiving a small accession of heat, moves the pitch, so as to cause bubbles to rise to the surface, and afford the mere semblance of a seething (pot).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:8
verses.text: The (sorcerer), however, previously washes his hands frequently in brine; the consequence being, that the contents of the cauldron do not in any wise, though in reality boiling, burn him very much.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:9
verses.text: But if, having smeared his hands with a tincture of myrtle and nitre and myrrh, along with vinegar, he wash them in brine frequently, he is not scorched: and he does not burn his feet, provided he smear them with isinglass and a salamander.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:10
verses.text: As regards, however, the burning like a taper of the pyramid, though composed of stone, the cause of this is the following.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:11
verses.text: Chalky earth is fashioned into the shape of a pyramid, but its colour is that of a milk-white stone, and it is prepared after this fashion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:12
verses.text: Having anointed the piece of clay with plenty of oil, and put it upon coals, and baked it, by smearing it afresh, and scorching it a second and third time, and frequently, (the sorcerer) contrives that it can be burned, even though he should plunge it in water; for it contains in itself abundance of oil.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:13
verses.text: The hearth, however, is spontaneously kindled, while the magician pours out a libation, by having lime instead of ashes burning underneath, and refined frankincense and a large quantity of tow, and a bundle of anointed tapers and of gall nuts, hollow within, and supplied with (concealed) fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:14
verses.text: And after some delay, (the sorcerer) makes (the pyramid) emit smoke from the mouth, by both putting fire in the gall nut, and encircling it with tow, and blowing into the mouth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:15
verses.text: The linen cloth, however, that has been placed round the cauldron, (and) on which he deposits the coals, on account of the underlying brine, would not be burned; besides, that it has itself been washed in brine, and then smeared with the white of an egg, along with moist alum.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 33:16
verses.text: And if, likewise, one mix in these the juice of house-leek along with vinegar, and for a long time previously smear it (with this preparation), after being washed in this drug, it continues altogether fire-proof.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:1
verses.text: The Illusion of the Sealed Letters; Object in Detailing These Juggleries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:2
verses.text: After, then, we have succinctly explained the powers of the secret arts practised among these (magicians), and have shown their easy plan for the acquisition of knowledge, neither are we disposed to be silent on the following point, which is a necessary one,—how that, loosing the seals, they restore the sealed letters, with the actual seals themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:3
verses.text: Melting pitch, resin, and sulphur, and moreover asphalt, in equal parts, (and) forming the ointment into a figure, they keep it by them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:4
verses.text: When, however, it is time to loose a small tablet, smearing with oil their tongue, next with the latter anointing the seal, (and) heating the drug with a moderate fire, (the sorcerers) place it upon the seal; and they leave it there until it has acquired complete consistence, and they use it in this condition as a seal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:5
verses.text: But they say, likewise, that wax itself with fir-wood gum possesses a similar potency, as well as two parts of mastich with one part of dry asphalt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:6
verses.text: But sulphur also by itself effects the purpose tolerably well, and flower of gypsum strained with water, and of gum.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:7
verses.text: Now this (last mixture) certainly answers most admirably also for sealing molten lead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:8
verses.text: And that which is accomplished by the Tuscan wax, and refuse of resin, and pitch, and asphalt, and mastich, and powdered spar, all being boiled together in equal parts, is superior to the rest of the drugs which I have mentioned, while that which is effected by the gum is not inferior.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:9
verses.text: In this manner, then, also, they attempt to loose the seals, endeavouring to learn the letters written within.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:10
verses.text: These contrivances, however, I hesitated to narrate in this book, perceiving the danger lest, perchance, any knavish person, taking occasion (from my account), should attempt (to practise these juggleries).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:11
verses.text: Solicitude, however, for many young persons, who could be preserved from such practices, has persuaded me to teach and publish, for security's sake, (the foregoing statements).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:12
verses.text: For although one person may make use of these for gaining instruction in evil, in this way somebody else will, by being instructed (in these practices), be preserved from them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:13
verses.text: And the magicians themselves, corrupters of life, will be ashamed in plying their art.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:14
verses.text: And learning these points that have been previously elucidated by us, they will possibly be restrained from their folly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 34:15
verses.text: But that this seal may not be broken, let me seal it with hog's lard and hair mixed with wax.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:1
verses.text: The Divination by a Cauldron; Illusion of Fiery Demons; Specimen of a Magical Invocation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:2
verses.text: But neither shall I be silent respecting that piece of knavery of these (sorcerers), which consists in the divination by means of the cauldron.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:3
verses.text: For, making a closed chamber, and anointing the ceiling with cyanus for present use, they introduce certain vessels of cyanus, and stretch them upwards.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:4
verses.text: The cauldron, however, full of water, is placed in the middle on the ground; and the reflection of the cyanus falling upon it, presents the appearance of heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:5
verses.text: But the floor also has a certain concealed aperture, on which the cauldron is laid, having been (previously, supplied with a bottom of crystal, while itself is composed of stone.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:6
verses.text: Underneath, however, unnoticed (by the spectators), is a compartment, into which the accomplices, assembling, appear invested with the figures of such gods and demons as the magician wishes to exhibit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:7
verses.text: Now the dupe, beholding these, becomes astonished at the knavery of the magician, and subsequently believes all things that are likely to be stated by him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:8
verses.text: But (the sorcerer) produces a burning demon, by tracing on the wall whatever figure he wishes, and then covertly smearing it with a drug mixed according to this manner, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:9
verses.text: , of Laconian and Zacynthian asphalt,—while next, as if under the influence of prophetic frenzy, he moves the lamp towards the wall.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:10
verses.text: The drug, however, is burned with considerable splendour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:11
verses.text: And that a fiery Hecate seems to career through air, he contrives in the mode following.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:12
verses.text: Concealing a certain accomplice in a place which he wishes, (and) taking aside his dupes, he persuades them (to believe himself), alleging that he will exhibit a flaming demon riding through the air.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:13
verses.text: Now he exhorts them immediately to keep their eyes fixed until they see the flame in the air, and that (then), veiling themselves, they should fall on their face until he himself should call them; and after having given them these instructions, he, on a moonless night, in verses speaks thus:—  "Infernal, and earthy, and supernal Bombo, come!  Saint of streets, and brilliant one, that strays by night;  Foe of radiance, but friend and mate of gloom;  In howl of dogs rejoicing, and in crimson gore,  Wading 'mid corpses through tombs of lifeless dust,  Panting for blood; with fear convulsing men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 35:14
verses.text: Gorgo, and Mormo, and Luna, and of many shapes,  Come, propitious, to our sacrificial rites!".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 36

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 36:1
verses.text: Mode of Managing an Apparition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 36:2
verses.text: And while speaking these words, fire is seen borne through the air; but the (spectators) being horrified at the strange apparition, (and) covering their eyes, fling themselves speechless to earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 36:3
verses.text: But the success of the artifice is enhanced by the following contrivance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 36:4
verses.text: The accomplice whom I have spoken of as being concealed, when he hears the incantation ceasing, holding a kite or hawk enveloped with tow, sets fire to it and releases it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 36:5
verses.text: The bird, however, frightened by the flame, is borne aloft, and makes a (proportionably) quicker flight, which these deluded persons beholding, conceal themselves, as if they had seen something divine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 36:6
verses.text: The winged creature, however, being whirled round by the fire, is borne whithersoever chance may have it, and burns now the houses, and now the courtyards.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 36:7
verses.text: Such is the divination of the sorcerers.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:1
verses.text: Illusive Appearance of the Moon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:2
verses.text: And they make moon and stars appear on the ceiling after this manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:3
verses.text: In the central part of the ceiling, having fastened a mirror, placing a dish full of water equally (with the mirror) in the central portion of the floor, and setting in a central place likewise a candle, emitting a faint light from a higher position than the dish,—in this way, by reflection, (the magician) causes the moon to appear by the mirror.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:4
verses.text: But frequently, also, they suspend on high from the ceiling, at a distance, a drum, but which, being covered with some garment, is concealed by the accomplice, in order that (the heavenly body) may not appear before the (proper) time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:5
verses.text: And afterwards placing a candle (within the drum), when the magician gives the signal to the accomplice, he removes so much of the covering as may be sufficient for effecting an imitation representing the figure of the moon as it is at that particular time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:6
verses.text: He smears, however, the luminous parts of the drum with cinnabar and gum; and having pared around the neck and bottom of a flagon of glass ready behind, he puts a candle in it, and places around it some of the requisite contrivances for making the figures shine, which some one of the accomplices has concealed on high; and on receiving the signal, he throws down from above the contrivances, so to make the moon appear descending from the sky.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:7
verses.text: And the same result is achieved by means of a jar in sylvan localities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:8
verses.text: For it is by means of a jar that the tricks in a house are performed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:9
verses.text: For having set up an altar, subsequently is (placed upon it) the jar, having a lighted lamp; when, however, there are a greater number of lamps, no such sight is displayed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 37:10
verses.text: After then the enchanter invokes the moon, he orders all the lights to be extinguished, yet that one be left faintly burning; and then the light, that which streams from the jar, is reflected on the ceiling, and furnishes to those present a representation of the moon; the mouth of the jar being kept covered for the time which it would seem to require, in order that the representation of full moon should be exhibited on the ceiling.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 38

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 38:1
verses.text: Illusive Appearance of the Stars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 38:2
verses.text: But the scales of fishes—for instance, the seahorse—cause the stars to appear to be; the scales being steeped in a mixture of water and gum, and fastened on the ceiling at intervals.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 39

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 39:1
verses.text: Imitation of an Earthquake.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 39:2
verses.text: The sensation of an earthquake they cause in such a way, as that all things seem set in motion; ordure of a weasel burned with a magnet upon coals (has this effect).

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 40

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 40:1
verses.text: Trick with the Liver.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 40:2
verses.text: And they exhibit a liver seemingly bearing an inscription in this manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 40:3
verses.text: With the left hand he writes what he wishes, appending it to the question, and the letters are traced with gall juice and strong vinegar.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 40:4
verses.text: Then taking up the liver, retaining it in the left hand, he makes some delay, and then it draws away the impression, and it is supposed to have, as it were, writing upon it.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 41

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 41:1
verses.text: Making a Skull Speak.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 41:2
verses.text: But putting a skull on the ground, they make it speak in this manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 41:3
verses.text: The skull itself is made out of the caul of an ox; and when fashioned into the requisite figure, by means of Etruscan wax and prepared gum, (and) when this membrane is placed around, it presents the appearance of a skull, which seems to all to speak when the contrivance operates; in the same manner as we have explained in the case of the (attendant) youths, when, having procured the windpipe of a crane, or some such long-necked animal, and attaching it covertly to the skull, the accomplice utters what he wishes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 41:4
verses.text: And when he desires (the skull) to become invisible, he appears as if burning incense, placing around, (for this purpose,) a quantity of coals; and when the wax catches the heat of these, it melts, and in this way the skull is supposed to become invisible.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 42

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 42:1
verses.text: The Fraud of the Foregoing Practices; Their Connection with Heresy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 42:2
verses.text: These are the deeds of the magicians, and innumerable other such (tricks) there are which work on the credulity of the dupes, by fair balanced words, and the appearance of plausible acts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 42:3
verses.text: And the heresiarchs, astonished at the art of these (sorcerers), have imitated them, partly by delivering their doctrines in secrecy and darkness, and partly by advancing (these tenets) as their own.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 42:4
verses.text: For this reason, being desirous of warning the multitude, we have been the more painstaking, in order not to omit any expedient practised by the magicians, for those who may be disposed to be deceived.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 42:5
verses.text: We have been however drawn, not unreasonably, into a detail of some of the secret (mysteries) of the sorcerers, which are not very requisite, to be sure, in reference to the subject taken in hand; yet, for the purpose of guarding against the villanous and incoherent art of magicians, may be supposed useful.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 42:6
verses.text: Since, therefore, as far as delineation is feasible, we have explained the opinions of all (speculators), exerting especial attention towards the elucidation of the opinions introduced as novelties by the heresiarchs; (opinions) which, as far as piety is concerned, are futile and spurious, and which are not, even among themselves, perhaps deemed worthy of serious consideration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 42:7
verses.text: (Having pursued this course of inquiry), it seems expedient that, by means of a compendious discourse, we should recall to the (reader's) memory statements that have been previously made.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:1
verses.text: Recapitulation of Theologies and Cosmogonies; System of the Persians; Of the Babylonians; The Egyptian Notion of Deity; Their Theology Based on a Theory of Numbers; Their System of Cosmogony.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:2
verses.text: Among all those who throughout the earth, as philosophers and theologians, have carried on investigations, has prevailed diversity of opinion concerning the Deity, as to His essence or nature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:3
verses.text: For some affirm Him to be fire, and some spirit, and some water, while others say that He is earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:4
verses.text: And each of the elements labours under some deficiency, and one is worsted by the other.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:5
verses.text: To the wise men of the world, this, however, has occurred, which is obvious to persons possessing intelligence; (I mean) that, beholding the stupendous works of creation, they were confused respecting the substance of existing things, supposing that these were too vast to admit of deriving generation from another, and at the same time (asserting) that neither the universe itself is God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:6
verses.text: As far as theology was concerned, they declared, however, a single cause for things that fall under the cognizance of vision, each supposing the cause which he adjudged the most reasonable; and so, when gazing on the objects made by God, and on those which are the most insignificant in comparison with His overpowering majesty, not, however, being able to extend the mind to the magnitude of God as He really is, they deified these (works of the external world).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:7
verses.text: But the Persians, supposing that they had penetrated more within the confines of the truth, asserted that the Deity is luminous, a light contained in air.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:8
verses.text: The Babylonians, however, affirmed that the Deity is dark, which very opinion also appears the consequence of the other; for day follows night, and night day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:9
verses.text: Do not the Egyptians, however, who suppose themselves more ancient than all, speak of the power of the Deity? (This power they estimate by) calculating these intervals of the parts (of the zodiac; and, as if) by a most divine inspiration, they asserted that the Deity is an indivisible monad, both itself generating itself, and that out of this were formed all things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:10
verses.text: For this, say they, being unbegotten, produces the succeeding numbers; for instance, the monad, superadded into itself, generates the duad; and in like manner, when superadded (into duad, triad, and so forth), produces the triad and tetrad, up to the decade, which is the beginning and end of numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:11
verses.text: Wherefore it is that the first and tenth monad is generated, on account of the decade being equipollent, and being reckoned for a monad, and (because) this multiplied ten times will become a hundred, and again becomes a monad, and the hundred multiplied ten times will produce a thousand, and this will be a monad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:12
verses.text: In this manner also the thousand multiplied ten times make up the full sum of a myriad; in like manner will it be a monad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:13
verses.text: But by a comparison of indivisible quantities, the kindred numbers of the monad comprehend , , ,.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:14
verses.text: There is also, however, a more natural relation of a different number to the monad, according to the arrangement of the orbit of six days' duration, (that is), of the duad, according to the position and division of even numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:15
verses.text: But the kindred number is  and.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:16
verses.text: These, however, taking from the monad of the numbers an idea of virtue, progressed up to the four elements; (I allude), of course, to spirit, and fire, and water, and earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:17
verses.text: And out of these having made the world, (God) framed it an ermaphrodite, and allocated two elements for the upper hemisphere, namely spirit and fire; and this is styled the hemisphere of the monad, (a hemisphere) beneficent, and ascending, and masculine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:18
verses.text: For, being composed of small particles, the monad soars into the most rarified and purest part of the atmosphere; and the other two elements, earth and water, being more gross, he assigned to the duad; and this is termed the descending hemisphere, both feminine and mischievous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:19
verses.text: And likewise, again, the upper elements themselves, when compared one with another, comprise in one another both male and female for fruitfulness and increase of the whole creation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:20
verses.text: And the fire is masculine, and the spirit feminine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:21
verses.text: And again the water is masculine, and the earth feminine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:22
verses.text: And so from the beginning fire consorted with spirit, and water with earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:23
verses.text: For as the power of spirit is fire, so also that of earth is water;…and the elements themselves, when computed and resolved by subtraction of enneads, terminate properly, some of them in the masculine number, and others of them in the feminine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:24
verses.text: And, again, the ennead is subtracted for this cause, because the three hundred and sixty parts of the entire (circle) consist of enneads, and for this reason the four regions of the world are circumscribed by ninety perfect parts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:25
verses.text: And light has been appropriated to the monad, and darkness to the duad, and life to light, according to nature, and death to the duad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:26
verses.text: And to life (has been appropriated) justice; and to death, injustice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:27
verses.text: Wherefore everything generated among masculine numbers is beneficent, while that (produced) among feminine (numbers) is mischievous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:28
verses.text: For instance, they pursue their calculations thus: monad—that we may commence from this—becomes , which (numbers) terminate in a monad by the subtraction of the ennead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 43:29
verses.text: In like manner, reckon thus: Duad becomes ; take away the enneads, it ends in a duad, and each reverts into its own peculiar (function).

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:1
verses.text: Egyptian Theory of Nature; Their Amulets.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:2
verses.text: For the monad, therefore, as being beneficent, they assert that there are consequently names ascending, and beneficent, and masculine, and carefully observed, terminating in an uneven number; whereas that those terminating in the even number have been supposed to be both descending, and feminine and malicious.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:3
verses.text: For they affirm that nature is made up of contraries, namely bad and good, as right and left, light and darkness, night and day, life and death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:4
verses.text: And moreover they make this assertion, that they have calculated the word "Deity," (and found that it reverts into a pentad with an ennead subtracted).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:5
verses.text: Now this name is an even number, and when it is written down (on some material) they attach it to the body, and accomplish cures by it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:6
verses.text: In this manner, likewise, a certain herb, terminating in this number, being similarly fastened around (the frame), operates by reason of a similar calculation of the number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:7
verses.text: Nay, even a doctor cures sickly people by a similar calculation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:8
verses.text: If, however, the calculation is contrary, it does not heal with facility.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:9
verses.text: Persons attending to these numbers reckon as many as are homogeneous according to this principle; some, however, according to vowels alone; whereas others according to the entire number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 44:10
verses.text: Such also is the wisdom of the Egyptians, by which, as they boast, they suppose that they cognise the divine nature.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 45

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 45:1
verses.text: Use of the Foregoing Discussions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 45:2
verses.text: It appears, then, that these speculations also have been sufficiently explained by us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 45:3
verses.text: But since I think that I have omitted no opinion found in this earthly and grovelling Wisdom, I perceive that the solicitude expended by us on these subjects has not been useless.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 45:4
verses.text: For we observe that our discourse has been serviceable not only for a refutation of heresies, but also in reference to those who entertain these opinions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 45:5
verses.text: Now these, when they encounter the extreme care evinced by us, will even be struck with admiration of our earnestness, and will not despise our industry and condemn Christians as fools when they discern the opinions to which they themselves have stupidly accorded their belief.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 45:6
verses.text: And furthermore, those who, desirous of learning, addict themselves to the truth, will be assisted by our discourse to become, when they have learned the fundamental principles of the heresies, more intelligent not only for the easy refutation of those who have attempted to deceive them, but that also, when they have ascertained the avowed opinions of the wise men, and have been made acquainted with them, that they shall neither be confused by them as ignorant persons would, nor become the dupes of certain individuals acting as if from some authority; nay, more than this, they shall be on their guard against those that are allowing themselves to become victims to these delusions.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:1
verses.text: The Astrotheosophists; Aratus Imitated by the Heresiarchs; His System of the Disposition of the Stars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:2
verses.text: Having sufficiently explained these opinions, let us next pass on to a consideration of the subject taken in hand, in order that, by proving what we have determined concerning heresies, and by compelling their (champions) to return to these several (speculators) their peculiar tenets, we may show the heresiarchs destitute (of a system); and by proclaiming the folly of those who are persuaded (by these heterodox tenets), we shall prevail on them to retrace their course to the serene haven of the truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:3
verses.text: In order, however, that the statements about to follow may seem more clear to the readers, it is expedient also to declare the opinions advanced by Aratus concerning the disposition of the stars of the heavens.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:4
verses.text: (And this is necessary), inasmuch as some persons, assimilating these (doctrines) to those declared by the Scriptures, convert (the holy writings) into allegories, and endeavour to seduce the mind of those who give heed to their (tenets), drawing them on by plausible words into the admission of whatever opinions they wish, (and) exhibiting a strange marvel, as if the assertions made by them were fixed among the stars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:5
verses.text: They, however, gazing intently on the very extraordinary wonder, admirers as they are of trifles, are fascinated like a bird called the owl, which example it is proper to mention, on account of the statements that are about to follow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:6
verses.text: The animal (I speak of) is, however, not very different from an eagle, either in size or figure, and it is captured in the following way:—The hunter of these birds, when he sees a flock of them lighting anywhere, shaking his hands, at a distance pretends to dance, and so by little and little draws near the birds.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:7
verses.text: But they, struck with amazement at the strange sight, are rendered unobservant of everything passing around them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:8
verses.text: But others of the party, who have come into the country equipped for such a purpose, coming from behind upon the birds, easily lay hold on them as they are gazing on the dancer.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:9
verses.text: Wherefore I desire that no one, astonished by similar wonders of those who interpret the (aspect of) heaven, should, like the owl, be taken captive.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:10
verses.text: For the knavery practised by such speculators may be considered dancing and silliness, but not truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 46:11
verses.text: Aratus, therefore, expresses himself thus:—  "Just as many are they; hither and thither they roll  Day by day o'er heav'n, endless, ever, (that is, every star),  Yet this declines not even little; but thus exactly  E'er remains with axis fixed and poised in every part  Holds earth midway, and heaven itself around conducts".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:1
verses.text: Opinions of the Heretics Borrowed from Aratus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:2
verses.text: Aratus says that there are in the sky revolving, that is, gyrating stars, because from east to west, and west to east, they journey perpetually, (and) in an orbicular figure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:3
verses.text: And he says that there revolves towards "The Bears" themselves, like some stream of a river, an enormous and prodigious monster, (the) Serpent; and that this is what the devil says in the book of Job to the Deity, when (Satan) uses these words: "I have traversed earth under heaven, and have gone around (it)," that is, that I have been turned around, and thereby have been able to survey the worlds.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:4
verses.text: For they suppose that towards the North Pole is situated the Dragon, the Serpent, from the highest pole looking upon all (the objects), and gazing on all the works of creation, in order that nothing of the things that are being made may escape his notice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:5
verses.text: For though all the stars in the firmament set, the pole of this (luminary) alone never sets, but, careering high above the horizon, surveys and beholds all things, and none of the works of creation, he says, can escape his notice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:6
verses.text: "Where chiefly  Settings mingle and risings one with other".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:7
verses.text: (Here Aratus) says that the head of this (constellation) is placed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:8
verses.text: For towards the west and east of the two hemispheres is situated the head of the Dragon, in order, he says, that nothing may escape his notice throughout the same quarter, either of objects in the west or those in the east, but that the Beast may know all things at the same time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:9
verses.text: And near the head itself of the Dragon is the appearance of a man, conspicuous by means of the stars, which Aratus styles a wearied image, and like one oppressed with labour, and he is denominated "Engonasis".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:10
verses.text: Aratus then affirms that he does not know what this toil is, and what this prodigy is that revolves in heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:11
verses.text: The heretics, however, wishing by means of this account of the stars to establish their own doctrines, (and) with more than ordinary earnestness devoting their attention to these (astronomic systems), assert that Engonasis is Adam, according to the commandment of God as Moses declared, guarding the head of the Dragon, and the Dragon (guarding) his heel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 47:12
verses.text: For so Aratus expresses himself:—  "The right-foot's track of the Dragon fierce possessing".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:1
verses.text: Invention of the Lyre; Allegorizing the Appearance and Position of the Stars; Origin of the Phoenicians; The Logos Identified by Aratus with the Constellation Canis; Influence of Canis on Fertility and Life Generally.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:2
verses.text: And (Aratus) says that (the constellations) Lyra and Corona have been placed on both sides near him,—now I mean Engonasis,—but that he bends the knee, and stretches forth both hands, as if making a confession of sin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:3
verses.text: And that the lyre is a musical instrument fashioned by Logos while still altogether an infant, and that Logos is the same as he who is denominated Mercury among the Greeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:4
verses.text: And Aratus, with regard to the construction of the lyre, observes:—  "Then, further, also near the cradle,  Hermes pierced it through, and said, Call it Lyre".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:5
verses.text: It consists of seven strings, signifying by these seven strings the entire harmony and construction of the world as it is melodiously constituted.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:6
verses.text: For in six days the world was made, and (the Creator) rested on the seventh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:7
verses.text: If, then, says (Aratus), Adam, acknowledging (his guilt) and guarding the head of the Beast, according to the commandment of the Deity, will imitate Lyra, that is, obey the Logos of God, that is, submit to the law, he will receive Corona that is situated near him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:8
verses.text: If, however, he neglect his duty, he shall be hurled downwards in company with the Beast that lies underneath, and shall have, he says, his portion with the Beast.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:9
verses.text: And Engonasis seems on both sides to extend his hands, and on one to touch Lyra, and on the other Corona—and this is his confession;—so that it is possible to distinguish him by means of this (sidereal) configuration itself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:10
verses.text: But Corona nevertheless is plotted against, and forcibly drawn away by another beast, a smaller Dragon, which is the offspring of him who is guarded by the foot of Engonasis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:11
verses.text: A man also stands firmly grasping with both hands, and dragging towards the space behind the Serpent from Corona; and he does not permit the Beast to touch Corona.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:12
verses.text: though making a violent effort to do so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:13
verses.text: And Aratus styles him Anguitenens, because he restrains the impetuosity of the Serpent in his attempt to reach Corona.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:14
verses.text: But Logos, he says, is he who, in the figure of a man, hinders the Beast from reaching Corona, commiserating him who is being plotted against by the Dragon and his offspring simultaneously.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:15
verses.text: These (constellations), "The Bears," however, he says, are two hebdomads, composed of seven stars, images of two creations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:16
verses.text: For the first creation, he affirms, is that according to Adam in labours, this is he who is seen "on his knees" (Engonasis).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:17
verses.text: The second creation, however, is that according to Christ, by which we are regenerated; and this is Anguitenens, who struggles against the Beast, and hinders him from reaching Corona, which is reserved for the man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:18
verses.text: But "The Great Bear" is, he says, Helice, symbol of a mighty world towards which the Greeks steer their course, that is, for which they are being disciplined.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:19
verses.text: And, wafted by the waves of life, they follow onwards, (having in prospect) some such revolving world or discipline or wisdom which conducts those back that follow in pursuit of such a world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:20
verses.text: For the term Helice seems to signify a certain circling and revolution towards the same points.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:21
verses.text: There is likewise a certain other "Small Bear" (Cynosuris), as it were some image of the second creation—that formed according to God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:22
verses.text: For few, he says, there are that journey by the narrow path.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:23
verses.text: But they assert that Cynosuris is narrow, towards which Aratus says that the Sidonians navigate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:24
verses.text: But Aratus has spoken partly of the Sidonians, (but means) the Phoenicians, on account of the existence of the admirable wisdom of the Phoenicians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:25
verses.text: The Greeks, however, assert that they are Phoenicians, who have migrated from (the shores of) the Red Sea into this country where they even at present dwell, for this is the opinion of Herodotus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:26
verses.text: Now Cynosura, he says, is this (lesser) Bear, the second creation; the one of limited dimensions, the narrow way, and not Helice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:27
verses.text: For he does not lead them back, but guides forward by a straight path, those that follow him being (the tail) of Canis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:28
verses.text: For Canis is the Logos, partly guarding and preserving the flock, that is plotted against by the wolves; and partly like a dog, hunting the beasts from the creation, and destroying them; and partly producing all things, and being what they express by the name "Cyon" (Canis), that is, generator.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:29
verses.text: Hence it is said, Aratus has spoken of the rising of Canis, expressing himself thus: "When, however, Canis has risen, no longer do the crops miss".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:30
verses.text: This is what he says: Plants that have been put into the earth up to the period of Canis' rising, frequently, though not having struck root, are yet covered with a profusion of leaves, and afford indications to spectators that they will be productive, and that they appear full of life, (though in reality) not having vitality in themselves from the root.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:31
verses.text: But when the rising of Canis takes place, the living are separated from the dead by Canis; for whatsoever plants have not taken root, really undergo putrefaction.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:32
verses.text: This Canis, therefore, he says, as being a certain divine Logos, has been appointed judge of quick and dead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:33
verses.text: And as (the influence of) Canis is observable in the vegetable productions of this world, so in plants of celestial growth—in men—is beheld the (power of the) Logos.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:34
verses.text: From some such cause, then, Cynosura, the second creation, is set in the firmament as an image of a creation by the Logos.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:35
verses.text: The Dragon, however, in the centre reclines between the two creations, preventing a transition of whatever things are from the great creation to the small creation; and in guarding those that are fixed in the (great) creation, as for instance Engonasis, observing (at the same time) how and in what manner each is constituted in the small creation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:36
verses.text: And (the Dragon) himself is watched at the head, he says, by Anguitenens.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:37
verses.text: This image, he affirms, is fixed in heaven, being a certain wisdom to those capable of discerning it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 48:38
verses.text: If, however, this is obscure, by means of some other image, he says the creation teaches (men) to philosophize, in regard to which Aratus has expressed himself thus:—  "Neither of Cepheus Iasidas are we the wretched brood".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 49

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 49:1
verses.text: Symbol of the Creature; And of Spirit; And of the Different Orders of Animals.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 49:2
verses.text: But Aratus says, near this (constellation) is Cepheus, and Cassiepea, and Andromeda, and Perseus, great lineaments of the creation to those who are able to discern them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 49:3
verses.text: For he asserts that Cepheus is Adam, Cassiepea Eve, Andromeda the soul of both of these, Perseus the Logos, winged offspring of Jove, and Cetos the plotting monster.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 49:4
verses.text: Not to any of these, but to Andromeda only does he repair, who slays the Beast; from whom, likewise taking unto himself Andromeda, who had been delivered (and) chained to the Beast, the Logos—that is, Perseus—achieves, he says, her liberation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 49:5
verses.text: Perseus, however, is the winged axle that pierces both poles through the centre of the earth, and turns the world round.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 49:6
verses.text: The spirit also, that which is in the world, is (symbolized by) Cycnus, a bird—a musical animal near "The Bears"—type of the Divine Spirit, because that when it approaches the end itself of life, it alone is fitted by nature to sing, on departing with good hope from the wicked creation, (and) offering up hymns unto God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 49:7
verses.text: But crabs, and bulls, and lions, and rams, and goats, and kids, and as many other beasts as have their names used for denominating the stars in the firmament, are, he says, images, and exemplars from which the creation, subject to change, obtaining (the different) species, becomes replete with animals of this description.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 50

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 50:1
verses.text: Folly of Astrology.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 50:2
verses.text: Employing these accounts, (the heretics) think to deceive as many of these as devote themselves over-sedulously to the astrologers, from thence striving to construct a system of religion that is widely divergent from the thoughts of these (speculators).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 50:3
verses.text: Wherefore, beloved, let us avoid the habit of admiring trifles, secured by which the bird (styled) the owl (is captured).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 50:4
verses.text: For these and other such speculations are, (as it were), dancing, and not Truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 50:5
verses.text: For neither do the stars yield these points of information; but men of their own accord, for the designation of certain stars, thus called them by names, in order that they might become to them easily distinguishable.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 50:6
verses.text: For what similarity with a bear or lion, or kid, or waterman, or Cepheus, or Andromeda, or the spectres that have names given them in Hades, have the stars that are scattered over the firmament—for we must remember that these men, and the titles themselves, came into existence long after the origin of man,—(what, I say, is in common between the two), that the heretics, astonished at the marvel, should thus strive by means of such discourses to strengthen their own opinions?.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:1
verses.text: The Hebdomadarii; System of the Arithmeticians; Pressed into the Service of Heresy; Instances Of, in Simon and Valentinus; The Nature of the Universe Deducible from the Physiology of the Brain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:2
verses.text: But since almost every heresy (that has sprung up) through the arithmetical art has discovered measures of hebdomads and certain projections of aeons, each rending the art differently, while whatever variation prevailed was in the names merely; and (since) Pythagoras became the instructor of these, first introducing numbers of this sort among the Greeks from Egypt, it seems expedient not to omit even this, but, after we have given a compendious elucidation, to approach the demonstration of those things that we propose to investigate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:3
verses.text: Arithmeticians and geometers arose, to whom especially Pythagoras first seems to have furnished principles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:4
verses.text: And from numbers that can continually progress ad infinitum by multiplication, and from figures, these derived their first principles, as capable of being discerned by reason alone; for a principle of geometry, as one may perceive, is an indivisible point.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:5
verses.text: From that point, however, by means of the art, the generation of endless figures from the point is discovered.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:6
verses.text: For the point being drawn into length becomes a line, after being thus continued, having a point for its extremity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:7
verses.text: And a line flowing out into breadth begets a surface, and the limits of the surface are lines; but a surface flowing out into breadth becomes body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:8
verses.text: And when what is solid has in this manner derived existence from, altogether, the smallest point, the nature of a huge body is constituted; and this is what Simon expresses thus: "The little will be great, being as a point, and the great illimitable".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:9
verses.text: Now this coincides with the geometrical doctrine of a point.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:10
verses.text: But of the arithmetical art, which by composition contains philosophy, number became a first principle, which is an indefinable and incomprehensible (entity), comprising in itself all the numbers that can go on ad infinitum by aggregation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:11
verses.text: But the first monad became a principle, according to substance, of the numbers, which (principle) is a male monad, pro-creating paternally all the rest of the numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:12
verses.text: Secondly, the duad is a female number, which by the arithmeticians is also itself denominated even.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:13
verses.text: Thirdly, the triad is a male number; this also it has been the usual custom of arithmeticians to style odd.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:14
verses.text: In addition to all these, the tetrad is a female number; and this same, because it is feminine, is likewise denominated even.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:15
verses.text: All the numbers therefore, taken generically, are four—number, however, as regards genus, is indefinite—from which, according to their system, is formed the perfect number—I mean the decade.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:16
verses.text: For one, two, three, four, become ten—as has been previously proved—if the proper denomination be preserved, according to substance, for each of the numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:17
verses.text: This is the sacred quaternion, according to Pythagoras, having in itself roots of an endless nature, that is, all other numbers; for eleven, and twelve, and the rest, derive the principle of generation from the ten.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:18
verses.text: Of this decade—the perfect number—there are called four parts—number, monad, power, cube—whose connections and mixtures take place for the generation of increase, according to nature completing the productive number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:19
verses.text: For when the square is multiplied into itself, it becomes a biquadratic; but when the square is multiplied into a cube, it becomes the product of a quadratic and cube; but when a cube is multiplied into a cube, it becomes the product of cube multiplied by cube.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:20
verses.text: Wherefore all the numbers are seven; so that the generation of things produced may be from the hebdomad—which is number, monad, power, cube, biquadratic, product of quadratic multiplied by cube, product of cube multiplied by cube.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:21
verses.text: Of this hebdomad Simon and Valentinus, having altered the names, detailed marvellous stories, from thence hastily adopting a system for themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:22
verses.text: For Simon employs his denominations thus: Mind, Intelligence, Name, Voice, Ratiocination, Reflection; and He who stood, stands, will stand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:23
verses.text: And Valentinus (enumerates them thus): Mind, Truth, Word, Life, Man, Church, and the Father, reckoned along with these, according to the same principles as those advanced by the cultivators of arithmetical philosophy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:24
verses.text: And (heresiarchs) admiring, as if unknown to the multitude, (this philosophy, and) following it, have framed heterodox doctrines devised by themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:25
verses.text: Some indeed, then, attempt likewise to form the hebdomads from the medical (art), being astonished at the dissection of the brain, asserting that the substance of the universe and the power of procreation and the Godhead could be ascertained from the arrangement of the brain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:26
verses.text: For the brain, being the dominant portion of the entire body, reposes calm and unmoved, containing within itself the spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:27
verses.text: Such an account, then, is not incredible, but widely differs from the conclusions which these (heretics) attempt to deduce from it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:28
verses.text: For the brain, on being dissected, has within it what may be called a vaulted chamber.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:29
verses.text: And on either side of this are thin membranes, which they term little wings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:30
verses.text: Now these are gently moved by the spirit, and in turn propel towards the cerebellum the spirit, which, careering through a certain blood-vessel like a reed, advances towards the pineal gland.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:31
verses.text: And near this is situated the entrance of the cerebellum, which admits the current of spirit, and distributes it into what is styled the spinal marrow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:32
verses.text: But from them the whole frame participates in the spiritual energy, inasmuch as all the arteries, like a branch, are fastened on from this blood-vessel, the extremity of which terminates in the genital blood-vessels, whence all the (animal) seeds proceeding from the brain through the loin are secreted (in the seminal glands).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:33
verses.text: The form, however, of the brain is like the head of a serpent, respecting which a lengthened discussion is maintained by the professors of knowledge, falsely so named, as we shall prove.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:34
verses.text: Six other coupling ligaments grow out of the brain, which, traversing round the head, and having their termination in (the head) itself, hold bodies together; but the seventh (ligament) proceeds from the cerebellum to the lower parts of the rest of the frame, as we have declared.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:35
verses.text: And respecting this there is an enlarged discussion, whence both Simon and Valentinus will be found both to have derived from this source starting-points for their opinions, and, though they may not acknowledge it, to be in the first instance liars, then heretics.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies I 51:36
verses.text: Since, then, it appears that we have sufficiently explained these tenets likewise, and that all the reputed opinions of this earthly philosophy have been comprised in four books; it seems expedient to proceed to a consideration of the disciples of these men, nay rather, those who have furtively appropriated their doctrines.
